name: Rooting For Tubers Festival
description: Get ready, Bangalore! Rooting for Tubers is back and better than ever. This year’s festival brings you an exciting mix of food, culture, and nature, all wrapped up in the humble yet powerful tuber. It’s a fun, family-friendly day out, co-curated by Spudnik Farms and culinary creatives, to celebrate the vibrant world of tubers. Come with your friends, family, or even solo, and immerse yourself in a one-of-a-kind experience exploring flavours, traditions, and sustainability!FESTIVAL ITINERARY10:00 - InaugurationWelcome to the Tuber Festival by Spudnik Farms10:15 - 11:15 - Songs from the Soil: Tuber Tales and Cultural TraditionsA performance by the Solega Community from the BR Hills facilitated by Samira Agnihotri11:30 - 12:30 - Roots of Tradition"Tubers, Culture, and Climate" by Anumitra Ghosh & Reshma12:45 - 1:45  - Nutrition Unpeeled"The Power of Tubers" by Gauravi Ashok2:00 - 3:00 - Tuber Myths and LegendsWorkshop by Dipali Khandelwal from The Kindness Meal3:15 - 4:15 - Fermenting RootsA hands-on tuber workshop with Kobo FermentaryALL DAY EVENTS10:30 - 4:30 - Tuber MelaExplore a vibrant market of diverse tubers, fresh produce, and unique flavours, connecting you to the earth and farmer communities from across India.10:30 - 4:30 - ALT Carb 2050An interactive installation that envisions a future where carbs and carbon emissions intertwine, inviting you to rethink your carb choices and their impact on body and planet.11:00 - 4:00 - RFT Game: Join the Tuber ChallengeAttendees will split into teams, each tied to a suit of cards. Teams compete through mini-games every half hour, with rankings at each round. Top teams collect cards, building up scores for a final tally.-----------------------------------------------------------------------JOIN US IN ROOTING FOR TUBERS!15+ Community & Market StallsExplore diverse stalls featuring local farmers, producers, and communities, all sharing unique tuber varieties and other farm-fresh produce. Discover exciting new ways to cook with tubers, support small-scale farmers, and stock up on your favourite finds at the market. Interact and meet various tuber growing communities from across India!Culinary Stalls & Live CookingWatch chefs in action as they cook up delicious tuber-inspired dishes! Learn from the best as they explore tubers in creative and sustainable ways, showcasing the potential of these crops in modern cooking.Workshops & TalksLearn from experts in hands-on workshops, including fermentation, traditional cooking methods, and nutrition. Engage in conversations around biodiversity, sustainable food systems, and the cultural significance of tubers, while interacting with both culinary professionals and farmers.Art Installation & Tuber DisplayDelve into the artistic side of tubers through a collaborative art installation, featuring a colourful display of various indigenous tuber varieties. Discover the beauty and biodiversity of tubers while learning about the role they play in climate resilience and food security.

7:20 PM : No Winter Holidays (Rajan Kathet, Sunir Pandey | Nepal, South Korea, Romania | 1 hr 19 mins | Nepali | 2023)7:20 - 8:00 PM : Sharing Circle NON-FILM PROGRAM DETAILS :ALT EFF Voices: ALT EFF Voices is a dynamic spoken-word platform that will be a key feature of our annual festival, providing a space for individuals to share their personal stories, thoughts, and observations on the pressing environmental challenges we face today. With ALT EFF Voices' inaugural edition during ALT EFF 2024, we hope people of all ages and backgrounds will feel free to channel their grief, anger, hope, and passion into powerful yet creative messages about our environment. Crisis of Consumption: India’s Overwhelming Waste Problem and What We Can Do About It What do fast fashion and animal agriculture have in common? This talk dives into the hidden impacts of our everyday choices and their toll on the environment. From the dyes in our clothing to the materials we often overlook, consumption patterns are driving a crisis. Color Ashram Foundation brings awareness to the toxic dyes used in the fashion industry and the massive waste created as a result. Consumers for Sustainability highlights the environmental costs of animal-derived materials like wool, leather, and silk—showing how these products consume water, pollute air and soil, and deplete precious land resources. Join us to discover the real costs behind these industries and explore pathways toward more sustainable choices.Speaker’s Bio:Seemanthini C. is the Project Coordinator at Consumers for Sustainability, an initiative dedicated to promoting consumer protection and fostering sustainable practices across sectors. With a background in biotechnology and a wealth of experience in organising educational camps and outreach programs, she is a strong advocate for capacity and community building. She believes these are essential tools for creating a ripple effect that strengthens the sustainability movement and inspires meaningful change.Namrata Bhutoria has been studying the toxic nature of colors - Chromatopia as a topic for long and has been able to successfully offer training and solutions in the form of natural colors. She believes that true learning happens with reflection, connection, and also brings personal transformation. She is passionate about educating young minds on the problems of synthetic color and reviving solutions in natural color application through curriculum and hands-on experiences.

Anthony Svatek | USA | 10 mins 37 secs | English | 2023)  INDIA PREMIERE1:10 - 1:30 PM : Wild Summon (Karni and Saul | UK | 14 mins 39 secs | English | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE1:30 - 1:45 PM : Lunatic Lunatic (Robin Noorda | Netherlands | 16 mins | English | 2024)1:45 - 2:00 PM : Break 2:00 - 2:15 PM : Covered in mud, buried under myths: Red sand boa illegal trade (Shatabdi Charkraborti | India | 13 mins 32 secs | English, Hindi | 2024)2:15 - 2:30 PM : Immaculate (Ningjing Wang | China, UK | 15 mins 40 secs | Chinese, English | 2024) INDIA PREMIERE2:30 - 3:15 PM : Crisis of Consumption: India’s Overwhelming Waste Problem and What We Can Do About It by Consumers for Sustainability 3:15 - 4:30 PM : Nenets vs Gas (Sergio Ghizzardi | France, Belgium, Norway, Finland | 1 hr 14 mins | English, Russian, Nenets | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE4:30 - 5:00 PM : ALT EFF Voices: With prompts and/or select curation provided by us, this is an open-mic for audiences to express themselvesNON FILM PROGRAM: ALT EFF VoicesALT EFF Voices is a dynamic spoken-word platform that will be a key feature of our annual festival, providing a space for individuals to share their personal stories, thoughts, and observations on the pressing environmental challenges we face today. With ALT EFF Voices' inaugural edition during ALT EFF 2024, we hope people of all ages and backgrounds will feel free to channel their grief, anger, hope, and passion into powerful yet creative messages about our environment.Fungal Entanglements: A Sensory Journey by Fungi Foundation‘Fungal Entanglements: A Sensory Journey’ is an immersive workshop that bridges art, science, and traditional ecological knowledge to explore the fascinating world of fungi. This multisensory experience, facilitated by Malavika Bhatia and Prithvi Kini of Fungi Foundation, is designed to engage participants with the often-overlooked realm of fungi, emphasising their ecological roles and relationships with other organisms, including humans.The workshop takes participants on a unique fungal adventure, engaging all five senses to foster a deeper understanding and appreciation of fungi. By intertwining scientific knowledge with sensory experiences and creative expression, the workshop aims to transform participants' perceptions of fungi from potential disgust to wonder and curiosity.Through a series of interactive stations, participants will explore fungal diversity, examine specimens under microscopes, experience various fungal scents and textures, taste edible mushrooms, and even listen to mushroom-generated music. The workshop culminates in an embodied activity where participants creatively express fungal relationships, fostering a personal connection to these remarkable organisms.Speaker’s Bio:Prithvi Kini is an entrepreneur, yoga practitioner, citizen scientist, and mental health advocate with a deep interest in the therapeutic benefits of mushrooms. As the co-founder of Nuvedo, India's pioneering functional mushroom start-up, her vision is for people to reclaim control of their lives through mushrooms. Through Nuvedo, she forges connections with local farming communities and myriad mycophiles across India and is fostering a mushroom revolution that goes beyond the world of business. With Fungi Foundation India, she's on a mission to revolutionize India's allyship with fungi, not just on a plate but in policy as well. With a commitment to conservation, her interests focus on ethical biodiversity research and Indian ethnomycological exploration. Her vision is to create a kinder, authentic and more accepting India through the power of fungi and applying to rekindle a ‘more-than-human’ outlook on our ways of life.Malavika Bhatia is a forager, artist, and community facilitator who weaves together ethnomycological research, community-based practices, and theoretical frameworks to reimagine relationships in the more-than-human world. Their art practice inhabits spaces of decay and decomposition, viewing these processes not as endpoints but as vital sites of regeneration and possibility. Through programs with Science Gallery Bengaluru, Kiran Nadar Museum of Art, Sandbox Collective, Serendipity Arts Festival, and others, they create participatory experiences that invite audiences to consider how fungal networks can serve as both metaphor and method for reimagining community relationships and ecological entanglements.Community Campaigning: Success Stories and A Pathway to Change	The session will be a deep-dive into the importance of engaging with communities for grassroots advocacy initiatives and impactful public mobilization through digital media. Jhatkaa.org will reflect on learnings from its successful campaigns that have harnessed the power of community support to create impact on a range of issues including environmental issues, social justice, and better urban planning. Additionally, successful local campaign case studies will also be sharedSpeaker’s Bio: Divya is the Executive Director of Jhatkaa.org, where she leads efforts to build an equitable, inclusive, and sustainable India. With a Master's degree in Public Health and Human Rights, Divya has over 12 years of experience working at the intersection of grassroots activism and digital advocacy, addressing critical issues in climate change, public health, and social justice.At Jhatkaa.org, she works with a team of campaigners and technologists to design and execute campaigns on a range of issues, including climate change, gender and sexuality, women's rights, and social justice. Jhatkaa.org leverages innovative technology and public mobilization to foster a movement of engaged and progressive Indians, empowering individuals to take collective action for systemic change.Divya also serves as an advisor and mentor to a regenerative communications agency, a trans rights organization, and other individual changemakers in India.Mongabay discussion moderated by ALT EFF rep Wild Frequencies at ALT EFFScience, Sound, and Story Walk into a PodcastJoin Abhijit Shylanath as he presents his experience working as a sound designer for Mongabay India’s Wild Frequencies. In this session, Abhijit will reveal the art and science behind using sound as the focal point to drive stories, creating impactful narratives without visuals. He will discuss the sound design process, editing techniques, and the essential role of editorial support in crafting powerful audio narratives. Abhijit brings unique insights on how to balance artistic storytelling with journalistic integrity, offering valuable lessons in creating compelling soundscapes that resonate with listeners.Speaker’s BioAbhijit Shylanath is a self-taught musician, producer, and audio editor. He has been making original music since age five and has a broad sonic palette from folk to indie rock to cinematic scores. Qualified as a computer engineer, he chose to work instead as a studio producer. He has 20+ years of experience making music for movies, corporate identities, events, video games, and ad campaigns. He is particularly interested in podcasts as a medium of communicating ideas and data, and believes that they have, like music, a deceptively long history of oral tradition behind them.Crisis of Consumption: India’s Overwhelming Waste Problem and What We Can Do About It What do fast fashion and animal agriculture have in common? This talk dives into the hidden impacts of our everyday choices and their toll on the environment. From the dyes in our clothing to the materials we often overlook, consumption patterns are driving a crisis. Color Ashram Foundation brings awareness to the toxic dyes used in the fashion industry and the massive waste created as a result. Consumers for Sustainability highlights the environmental costs of animal-derived materials like wool, leather, and silk—showing how these products consume water, pollute air and soil, and deplete precious land resources. Join us to discover the real costs behind these industries and explore pathways toward more sustainable choices.Speaker’s Bio:Seemanthini C. is the Project Coordinator at Consumers for Sustainability, an initiative dedicated to promoting consumer protection and fostering sustainable practices across sectors. With a background in biotechnology and a wealth of experience in organising educational camps and outreach programs, she is a strong advocate for capacity and community building. She believes these are essential tools for creating a ripple effect that strengthens the sustainability movement and inspires meaningful change.Moving Into A Climate Solutions Economy: Climate Futures and the role of Forests by Land Conflict WatchIndia has announced that it would create an additional carbon sink of 3.0 billion tonnes by increasing forest cover by 2030. To achieve this, the country has put in place a dedicated policy to carry out afforestation to compensate for the forests it loses to industries and other project developers. However, how well has this panned out on the ground? Forest communities, who had to give up forest lands that they were dependent on to industries years ago, are now being displaced again as the state is struggling for land to meet its afforestation target. Has the role of forests been reduced to only carbon sequestration?  Speaker’s BioKumar Sambhav Shrivastava Founder & Director, Land Conflict WatchKumar Sambhav is a social entrepreneur and award-winning journalist, leading innovative research in accountability investigations. He is the founder of Land Conflict Watch and is currently working as India Research Lead with Princeton University’s Digital Witness Lab. Kumar co-founded The Reporters’ Collective, a non-profit journalism collaborative in India and was an inaugural Artificial Intelligence Accountability Fellow with the Pulitzer Center. Kumar has reported for prime global and Indian news outlets, including Al Jazeera, Huffington Post, Business Standard, Hindustan Times, Down To Earth and The Times of India. He has received the prestigious Red Ink Award, the Press Council of India’s National Award for Excellence in Journalism and the Shriram Award for Excellence in Financial Journalism. Mrinali Advisor & Climate Research Lead, Land Conflict WatchMrinali K works as Advisor & Climate Research Lead, Land Conflict Watch. Her research focuses on issues of climate change and resource conflicts. For more than 6 years now, she has studied issues around land and resource conflicts, working with journalists and researchers to conduct research around the land conflict database. She has also tracked and reported on international climate change negotiations since 2022.

description: Since the dawn of time, storytelling in community has shaped our mindset, our outlook and ultimately, our behaviour. With record heat, oscillating droughts & floods, fires, melting glaciers (and ... you know the rest) our current narrative needs some course correcting.All Living Things Environmental Film Festival (ALT EFF) is back for a 5th edition, pan-India cultural event. Join us at MEDAI for a unique evening of cinema, art & community. Watch award-winning global films on regeneration, activism, resilience and hope and engage in conversations with India’s most inspiring change-makers. Let’s restore the narrative of stewardship, together. 1:10 PM : Some Thoughts on the Common Toad (G. Anthony Svatek | USA | 10 mins 37 secs | English | 2023)  INDIA PREMIERE1:10 - 1:30 PM : Wild Summon (Karni and Saul | UK | 14 mins 39 secs | English | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE1:30 - 1:45 PM : Lunatic Lunatic (Robin Noorda | Netherlands | 16 mins | English | 2024)1:45 - 2:00 PM : Break 2:00 - 2:15 PM : Covered in mud, buried under myths: Red sand boa illegal trade (Shatabdi Charkraborti | India | 13 mins 32 secs | English, Hindi | 2024)2:15 - 2:30 PM : Immaculate (Ningjing Wang | China, UK | 15 mins 40 secs | Chinese, English | 2024) INDIA PREMIERE2:30 - 3:15 PM : Crisis of Consumption: India’s Overwhelming Waste Problem and What We Can Do About It by Consumers for Sustainability 3:15 - 4:30 PM : Nenets vs Gas (Sergio Ghizzardi | France, Belgium, Norway, Finland | 1 hr 14 mins | English, Russian, Nenets | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE4:30 - 5:00 PM : ALT EFF Voices: With prompts and/or select curation provided by us, this is an open-mic for audiences to express themselvesNON FILM PROGRAM: ALT EFF VoicesALT EFF Voices is a dynamic spoken-word platform that will be a key feature of our annual festival, providing a space for individuals to share their personal stories, thoughts, and observations on the pressing environmental challenges we face today. With ALT EFF Voices' inaugural edition during ALT EFF 2024, we hope people of all ages and backgrounds will feel free to channel their grief, anger, hope, and passion into powerful yet creative messages about our environment.Fungal Entanglements: A Sensory Journey by Fungi Foundation‘Fungal Entanglements: A Sensory Journey’ is an immersive workshop that bridges art, science, and traditional ecological knowledge to explore the fascinating world of fungi. This multisensory experience, facilitated by Malavika Bhatia and Prithvi Kini of Fungi Foundation, is designed to engage participants with the often-overlooked realm of fungi, emphasising their ecological roles and relationships with other organisms, including humans.The workshop takes participants on a unique fungal adventure, engaging all five senses to foster a deeper understanding and appreciation of fungi. By intertwining scientific knowledge with sensory experiences and creative expression, the workshop aims to transform participants' perceptions of fungi from potential disgust to wonder and curiosity.Through a series of interactive stations, participants will explore fungal diversity, examine specimens under microscopes, experience various fungal scents and textures, taste edible mushrooms, and even listen to mushroom-generated music. The workshop culminates in an embodied activity where participants creatively express fungal relationships, fostering a personal connection to these remarkable organisms.Speaker’s Bio:Prithvi Kini is an entrepreneur, yoga practitioner, citizen scientist, and mental health advocate with a deep interest in the therapeutic benefits of mushrooms. As the co-founder of Nuvedo, India's pioneering functional mushroom start-up, her vision is for people to reclaim control of their lives through mushrooms. Through Nuvedo, she forges connections with local farming communities and myriad mycophiles across India and is fostering a mushroom revolution that goes beyond the world of business. With Fungi Foundation India, she's on a mission to revolutionize India's allyship with fungi, not just on a plate but in policy as well. With a commitment to conservation, her interests focus on ethical biodiversity research and Indian ethnomycological exploration. Her vision is to create a kinder, authentic and more accepting India through the power of fungi and applying to rekindle a ‘more-than-human’ outlook on our ways of life.Malavika Bhatia is a forager, artist, and community facilitator who weaves together ethnomycological research, community-based practices, and theoretical frameworks to reimagine relationships in the more-than-human world. Their art practice inhabits spaces of decay and decomposition, viewing these processes not as endpoints but as vital sites of regeneration and possibility. Through programs with Science Gallery Bengaluru, Kiran Nadar Museum of Art, Sandbox Collective, Serendipity Arts Festival, and others, they create participatory experiences that invite audiences to consider how fungal networks can serve as both metaphor and method for reimagining community relationships and ecological entanglements.Community Campaigning: Success Stories and A Pathway to Change	The session will be a deep-dive into the importance of engaging with communities for grassroots advocacy initiatives and impactful public mobilization through digital media. Jhatkaa.org will reflect on learnings from its successful campaigns that have harnessed the power of community support to create impact on a range of issues including environmental issues, social justice, and better urban planning. Additionally, successful local campaign case studies will also be sharedSpeaker’s Bio: Divya is the Executive Director of Jhatkaa.org, where she leads efforts to build an equitable, inclusive, and sustainable India. With a Master's degree in Public Health and Human Rights, Divya has over 12 years of experience working at the intersection of grassroots activism and digital advocacy, addressing critical issues in climate change, public health, and social justice.At Jhatkaa.org, she works with a team of campaigners and technologists to design and execute campaigns on a range of issues, including climate change, gender and sexuality, women's rights, and social justice. Jhatkaa.org leverages innovative technology and public mobilization to foster a movement of engaged and progressive Indians, empowering individuals to take collective action for systemic change.Divya also serves as an advisor and mentor to a regenerative communications agency, a trans rights organization, and other individual changemakers in India.Mongabay discussion moderated by ALT EFF rep Wild Frequencies at ALT EFFScience, Sound, and Story Walk into a PodcastJoin Abhijit Shylanath as he presents his experience working as a sound designer for Mongabay India’s Wild Frequencies. In this session, Abhijit will reveal the art and science behind using sound as the focal point to drive stories, creating impactful narratives without visuals. He will discuss the sound design process, editing techniques, and the essential role of editorial support in crafting powerful audio narratives. Abhijit brings unique insights on how to balance artistic storytelling with journalistic integrity, offering valuable lessons in creating compelling soundscapes that resonate with listeners.Speaker’s BioAbhijit Shylanath is a self-taught musician, producer, and audio editor. He has been making original music since age five and has a broad sonic palette from folk to indie rock to cinematic scores. Qualified as a computer engineer, he chose to work instead as a studio producer. He has 20+ years of experience making music for movies, corporate identities, events, video games, and ad campaigns. He is particularly interested in podcasts as a medium of communicating ideas and data, and believes that they have, like music, a deceptively long history of oral tradition behind them.Crisis of Consumption: India’s Overwhelming Waste Problem and What We Can Do About It What do fast fashion and animal agriculture have in common? This talk dives into the hidden impacts of our everyday choices and their toll on the environment. From the dyes in our clothing to the materials we often overlook, consumption patterns are driving a crisis. Color Ashram Foundation brings awareness to the toxic dyes used in the fashion industry and the massive waste created as a result. Consumers for Sustainability highlights the environmental costs of animal-derived materials like wool, leather, and silk—showing how these products consume water, pollute air and soil, and deplete precious land resources. Join us to discover the real costs behind these industries and explore pathways toward more sustainable choices.Speaker’s Bio:Seemanthini C. is the Project Coordinator at Consumers for Sustainability, an initiative dedicated to promoting consumer protection and fostering sustainable practices across sectors. With a background in biotechnology and a wealth of experience in organising educational camps and outreach programs, she is a strong advocate for capacity and community building. She believes these are essential tools for creating a ripple effect that strengthens the sustainability movement and inspires meaningful change.Moving Into A Climate Solutions Economy: Climate Futures and the role of Forests by Land Conflict WatchIndia has announced that it would create an additional carbon sink of 3.0 billion tonnes by increasing forest cover by 2030. To achieve this, the country has put in place a dedicated policy to carry out afforestation to compensate for the forests it loses to industries and other project developers. However, how well has this panned out on the ground? Forest communities, who had to give up forest lands that they were dependent on to industries years ago, are now being displaced again as the state is struggling for land to meet its afforestation target. Has the role of forests been reduced to only carbon sequestration?  Speaker’s BioKumar Sambhav Shrivastava Founder & Director, Land Conflict WatchKumar Sambhav is a social entrepreneur and award-winning journalist, leading innovative research in accountability investigations. He is the founder of Land Conflict Watch and is currently working as India Research Lead with Princeton University’s Digital Witness Lab. Kumar co-founded The Reporters’ Collective, a non-profit journalism collaborative in India and was an inaugural Artificial Intelligence Accountability Fellow with the Pulitzer Center. Kumar has reported for prime global and Indian news outlets, including Al Jazeera, Huffington Post, Business Standard, Hindustan Times, Down To Earth and The Times of India. He has received the prestigious Red Ink Award, the Press Council of India’s National Award for Excellence in Journalism and the Shriram Award for Excellence in Financial Journalism. Mrinali Advisor & Climate Research Lead, Land Conflict WatchMrinali K works as Advisor & Climate Research Lead, Land Conflict Watch. Her research focuses on issues of climate change and resource conflicts. For more than 6 years now, she has studied issues around land and resource conflicts, working with journalists and researchers to conduct research around the land conflict database. She has also tracked and reported on international climate change negotiations since 2022.

name: In the footsteps of the Tiger of Mysore.
description: Discover the history of Bangalore fort, its tales of glory & treachery over the past five centuries with us.The walk begins with a vegetarian breakfast. After that we take our guests to explore the remnants of Tipu's summer palace, the Bangalore fort & the armory.During the course of the walk learn how Anglo-French wars in Europe & North America had their impact in Southern India too.The guests get to learn more about Tipu's weapons on mass destruction of the 18th century & how they influenced the US national anthem & how one small Southern Indian kingdom was a thorn in the East India Company's rule.

location.address: XH5F+PFR, Tippu Sultan Palace Rd, Chamrajpet, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560018, India

organizer.name: Bengaluru by foot
organizer.description: Heritage, food & architectural walks in Bangalore.

name: Malleswara Darshan heritage walk.
description: This is our walk in one of the oldest suburbs of the "old Bangalore". Join us on a 'darshan' of the many temples and other religious institutes that dot this area as we narrate to you its origins and about the celebrities/personalities who called it their 'home'. Also on this walk learn more about the Maratha connection to this neighborhood as well as how a philanthropist not only helped renovate the Kadu Malleswara temple but also helped create an entire lake in the days gone by.See how Kadu Malleswara turned into a "Mall-e-swarm" and is fast losing not only it's heritage structures but also its local culture. In between all the bytes of history we take bites from an iconic eatery in the this area.So join us on this walk next and get to know Malleswaram in a completely new light.

name: Charlie Chaplin's Modern Times (1936) Movie Screening | Family Movie Night
description: Family Movie Night at The Studio, Courtyard, ShantinagarJoin us as we watch a series of carefully curated rare masterpieces from around the world, made just for kids. Watch this film while cozying up with your family!Given the nature of the film, we recommend it for children aged 7 and older.About the movie:Modern Times (1936) is a silent comedy film directed by and starring Charlie Chaplin. The movie is set during the Great Depression and follows Chaplin's iconic character, the Tramp, as he struggles to survive in a rapidly industrializing world.The film opens with the Tramp working on an assembly line at a factory, where he is driven to the brink of madness by the repetitive and dehumanizing nature of the work. He eventually loses his job and ends up in prison, only to be released into a harsh society where unemployment and poverty are widespread.Why should your kid attend this screening? Introduction to Classic Cinema: It’s a great way to introduce children to the history of film, particularly silent films and early cinema. The visual storytelling and Chaplin's physical comedy are timeless and can inspire an appreciation for film artistry.Slapstick Humor: The film’s use of slapstick comedy — exaggerated physical actions and visual gags — is entertaining for kids and can help them develop an understanding of humor that transcends language.Social Awareness: The film subtly introduces children to concepts of social justice, equality, and the effects of industrialization on society. It can spark discussions about empathy, the challenges people face, and the importance of fairness.Cultural and Historical Context: Watching Modern Times gives kids a sense of history, particularly the Great Depression, and how it affected people's lives. It can encourage curiosity about the past and promote understanding of how society has evolved.And it's Charlie Chaplin!!!!Don't miss this opportunity to create lasting memories with your family while exposing your kids to the wonders of world cinema.Join us for Family Movie Night – where the magic of storytelling knows no bounds!Terms and Conditions:The management is not responsible for any injury or damage that may occur during the event.The Event is taking place at Courtyard's indoor Studio space on the second floor.No liability or claims arising from the consumption or intake of any food or drink will be entertained by the management.Parking near the event premises is at the risk of the vehicle owner.Children above the age of 3 need a ticket to attend the event.Valet service is available at a charge of Rs. 200 per vehicle.Photographs and videos of ticket holders may be uploaded to social media. If you prefer not to be featured, please inform our team.Tickets are non-refundable in case of cancellation or no-show.

name: ALT EFF 2024 x ATREE
description: Since the dawn of time, storytelling in community has shaped our mindset, our outlook and ultimately, our behavior. With record heat, oscillating droughts & floods, fires, melting glaciers (and ... you know the rest) our current narrative needs some course correcting.All Living Things Environmental Film Festival (ALT EFF) is back for a 5th edition, pan-India cultural event. Join us at ATREE for a unique evening of cinema, art & community. Watch award-winning global films on regeneration, activism, resilience and hope and engage in conversations with India’s most inspiring change-makers. Let’s restore the narrative of stewardship, together. All are welcome!PROGRAM:22nd November, Friday10:00 - 10:15 AM - Some Thoughts on the Common Toad (G. Anthony Svatek | USA | 10 mins 37 secs | English | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE10:15 - 10:25 AM - Understorey (Claire Riverland, Lily Newcombe | Australia, Malaysia | 07 mins 06 secs | English | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE10:25 - 10:40 AM - The Legend of Goldhorn (Lea Vucko | Slovenia | 13 mins 35 secs | No Dialogue | 2022) 10:40 - 11:00 AM - Discussion/sharing circle11:00 AM - 12:40 PM - My Mercury (Joëlle Chesselet, Pippa Erhlich | UK, USA | 1 hr 37 mins | English | 2023)12:40 - 01:00 PM - Discussion/sharing circle01:00 - 02:00 PM - Lunch2:00 - 3:15 PM - The Night Visitors (Michael Gitlin | USA | 1 hr 12 mins | English | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE3:15 - 4:00 PM - Discussion/Panel (by ATREE)04:00 - 04:15 PM - Tea Break04:15 - 06:05 PM - Sanctuary (Min-cheol Wang | South Korea | 1 hr 49 mins | Korean | 2022) INDIA PREMIERE23rd November, Saturday10:00 - 10:15 AM - Immaculate (Ningjing Wang | China, UK | 15 mins 40 secs | Chinese, English | 2024) INDIA PREMIERE10:15 - 10:35 AM - Requiem for a Whale (Ido Weisman | Israel | 15 mins 27 secs | Hebrew | 2022)10:15 - 11:45 AM - Send Kelp! (Blake McWilliam | Canada | 1 hr 29 mins | English | 2024) INDIA PREMIERE11:45 AM - 12:15 PM - Discussion/sharing circle12:15 - 01:00 PM - Lunch01:00 - 02:00 PM - Walking along rivers & Collaborative Climate Action by Veditum (Siddharth Agarwal, Founder-Director)02:00 - 02:15 PM - Lullaby of waves (Ayon Pratim Saikia | India | 15 mins 20 secs | Assamese | 2023) 02:15 - 02:35 PM -Last Days of Summer (Stenzin Tankong | India, France | 14 mins 57 secs | Boti (Ladakhi) | 2023)02:35 - 02:55 PM - Lunatic (Robin Noorda | Netherlands | 16 mins | English | 2024)02:55 - 03:15 PM - A Body Called Life (Spencer MacDonald | USA, Switzerland, Poland | 14 mins 51 secs | English | 2024) INDIA PREMIERE03:15 - 04:00 PM - Discussion/Sharing circle04:00 - 04:15 PM - Tea Break04:15 - 05:45 PM - The Giants (Laurence Billiet, Rachael Antony | Australia | 1 hr 30 mins | English | 2023) INDIA PREMIERE05:45 - 06:00 PM - Discussion and Closing NoteNON-FILM PROGRAM DETAILS :Walking along rivers & Collaborative Climate ActionWhat lessons did we learn from walking over 6000kms along India’s rivers? What are the challenges our rivers and communities living along rivers face? Listen to Siddharth Agarwal share river stories from Veditum India Foundation’s Moving Upstream project, and how we’re creating systems for collaborative climate action.Speaker’s Bio:Siddharth Agarwal has been walking across India and along India’s rivers, attempting to document and bring stories of marginalised communities and the environment into the mainstream. Since 2014, he has walked over 6000kms on these trails, including the lengths of the rivers Ganga and Ken. He is the founder of Veditum India Foundation.

name: Self-defence Workshop by F.L.A.G (Fight Like a Girl)
description: We’re excited to announce an empowering event tailored for women of all backgrounds: F.L.A.G. - Fight Like A Girl. Join us this weekend for an inspiring self-defense workshop that strengthens not just the body, but also the mind and spirit.In this two-hour session, we’ll explore physical techniques, mental resilience, and emotional strength, led by dedicated professionals who are here to support and uplift. Here’s what to expect:Strength Mapper – Get your heart pumping with cardio, agility, and reflex exercises designed to reveal your unique strengths.Self-Defense Scenarios – Practical, hands-on techniques for six common real-life situations, helping you feel prepared and empowered.Professional Guidance – A chance to train with skilled coaches and address personal safety challenges.Q&A Session – An open space to ask questions, learn from others, and build community support.Lifestyle Integration – Wrap up with practical strategies to keep these skills part of your everyday life.Join us to gain practical tools, connect with other amazing women, and walk away feeling stronger, inside and out.

description: Get Ready for the Ultimate Holiday Swap+Shop at Fashion Garage: Holiday Edition!Join us for a one-of-a-kind sustainable fashion festival, where you can refresh your wardrobe, find ‘new-to-you’ treasures, and enjoy an unforgettable day with fellow fashion enthusiasts! name: Pettah walk in Nagarathpet : Tales of Sufis, Silk & Shakti.
description: On this fourth walk of our's in Kempe Gowda's "Pettah" area we take the guests on a darshan of one of the most popular temples in Bangalore which is also associated with the popular Karaga festival.Join us as we take a walk along the narrow meandering lanes of the Pettah to know about it's history as well as discover monuments hidden behind modern buildings.As we take you through the lanes we stop at the factory where the famous Mysore rockets were made & how they influenced the US national anthem. We also stop at a place connected to India's freedom struggle. After that we pay a quick visit to the silk weavers in the neighborhood.If we still have time we might also pay our respects at the tombs of a few Sufi warriors who were martyred during the III Anglo-Mysore war in 1791.Last but not the least we have breakfast at a legendary food spot.

name: River Realms:An Immersive VR experience@Panchavati
description: This event is a part of Bengaluru Habba, a citywide Arts and Culture fest from Nov 30 - Dec 16Bengaluru—a city of innovation, growth, and resilience, sustaining millions each day. But have you ever wondered what truly fuels this metropolis? Over 100 km away lies its lifeline: the Cauvery River, the single source capable of quenching the city’s vast thirst. Rising to an elevation of 920 meters above sea level, every drop that reaches Bengaluru is part of an awe-inspiring engineering feat, delivering life-giving water across immense distances and elevations. While this feat of human ingenuity is indeed impressive, it underscores a critical reality: the city’s reliance on a distant water source is a fragile solution, one that becomes increasingly unsustainable as demand grows.In this immersive experience on the Apple Vision Pro, transport to the heart of the Cauvery in a way like never before. With stunning 16K 180° video narration, stories of conservation and wildlife, you’ll feel the river’s currents as if you’re standing on its banks, surrounded by the beauty of lush landscapes, misty hills, and abundant wildlife. Glide along the river and experience the peaceful yet powerful journey of its waters, as they make their way to our city.Dive Deeper with AR and 3D ModelsGet up close with interactive 3D models that reveal the rich wildlife, diverse plants, and the complex infrastructure behind this remarkable journey. Watch as dams, pipelines, and pumping stations come to life, illustrating the sophisticated system that transports Cauvery’s finite waters over vast distances to sustain Bengaluru. Feel the river's flow, witness the delicate balance between nature and engineering, and understand both the marvel and the responsibility of relying on a distant water source.An Experience Like No OtherThis is more than just an experience—it’s an invitation to understand the delicate balance that keeps Bengaluru thriving. Join us at Bengaluru Hubba on the Apple Vision Pro for “Bengaluru: A City Fueled by the Cauvery” Discover the lifeblood of our city, and be part of the journey that brings water, life, and hope to millions.

Join us at Bengaluru Hubba on the Apple Vision Pro for “Bengaluru: A City Fueled by the Cauvery” Discover the lifeblood of our city, and be part of the journey that brings water, life, and hope to millions.

But have you ever wondered what truly fuels this metropolis? Over 100 km away lies its lifeline: the Cauvery River, the single source capable of quenching the city’s vast thirst. name: Come Experience Badaga Cuisine
description: A Culinary Journey into Badaga Cuisine at THE Park BangaloreMonsoon, the 24-hour dining restaurant at THE Park Bangalore, invites diners to explore the rich heritage of Badaga cuisine from the Nilgiri hills. From November 22nd to 24th, 2024, experience an exclusive five-course meal crafted in collaboration with educationist-turned-restaurateur Dr. Suresh Belliraj and his family. Dr. Belliraj, who runs Odae restaurant in the Nilgiris, introduced this Badaga-inspired meal as a tribute to his heritage. The menu was curated by his sister Chitra Devaraj and mother Meenakshi Belliraj, with contributions from the entire family.  Badaga cuisine reflects the community's harmonious relationship with nature, featuring indigenous ingredients like ragi, little millet, and high-grown wheat. Their primarily vegetarian diet incorporates foraged vegetables, greens, and root crops, with meat consumed sparingly. Traditionally served on large metal platters called ganguwa, this cuisine is nutrient-rich and ideal for enduring cold monsoons.  The five-course menu highlights traditional dishes such as:  Pothithu – Whole Wheat Pancakes with Honey  - Erigihittu/Sandagai – Ragi Balls with Garlic Chutney  - Koi Uthukka – Chicken Curry with Old-Style Bread  - Nilagiri Kurma – Mixed Vegetable Curry with Old-Style Bread  - Badu Uthukka – Mutton Curry with Rice  - Avarai Uthukka – Bean Curry with Rice  Accompaniments include spiced coconut milk as a palate cleanser and digestive items like domba rasa (tomato-garlic rasam) and majjige hittu (little millet in buttermilk). For dessert, indulge in ennaihittu (sweet paniyaram) and hatchikkai (popped millet with coconut milk).  Celebrate this unique culinary journey, blending tradition and family legacy, at Monsoon.

name: Thanksgiving Sharing Feast
description: Join us at the Studio by Copper + Cloves for a traditional, nourishing Thanksgiving dinner, in collaboration with Origin.We'll be cooking all day to bring you a produce-centred menu inspired by classic holiday favourites: stuffed mini-butternut squash, leek & sage stuffing, roasted sweet potatoes with rosemary, pumpkin pie, and cranberries—made from wholesome, seasonal ingredients sourced from Origin.We want to celebrate the true spirit of Thanksgiving with you- full of gratitude, meaningful conversations, and a cosy candlelit atmosphere. We’ll share a gratitude game to spark new connections, surrounded by a beautifully curated tablescape featuring fall produce from Origin.To start, we will celebrate with a festive zero-proof cocktail before taking a seat at the table for a family-style evening of food and connection.📅 Secure your spot now—tickets are limited.

description: Experience the joy of crafting something beautiful out of paper. Origami is the japanese art of paper folding. A perfect activity for DIY and craft enthusiasts. In this fun filled session you will be introduced to some basic folding techniques in Origami and make a kimono jacket with hakama pants. This workshop is beginner friendly and does not require any prior knowledge of origami.

name: PowerPoint Roulette by Improv Lore
description: PowerPoint Roulette is a fast-paced, creative show where improvisers deliver presentations from slides they’ve never seen before. Each performer is faced with slides filled with bizarre graphs, meaningless acronyms, and unexpected themes. With no time to prepare, they must improvise convincing explanations, facts, stories, and insights on the spot.Serious business pitches, heartfelt eulogies, hard-hitting TED talks, and fanciful conspiracy theories - prepare yourselves for a night ‘official’ fun! The audience gets to join the revelry by asking questions, creating a truly unpredictable night of improvised theatrics.

name: Yin Yoga with Franzi
description: We welcome you to come experience Yin Yoga that can be a deeply nurturing and grounding practice. Franzi will lead the session by helping you set an intention for releasing any tension or emotions that no longer serve you and embrace the soothing energy of the space during your Yin Yoga practice.In Yin Yoga, you can focus on poses that target the connective tissues, allowing for deep stretching and relaxation.Remember to listen to your body and honor where you are at emotionally and physically during your practice and focus on poses that promote feelings of sweetness, gratitude, and abundance.Set an intention to invite more sweetness and abundance into your life, both on and off the mat. Allow yourself to fully embrace the energy of the space and let it guide you through a nourishing and heart-centered Yin Yoga practice.

name: The Analog Club
description: Step back in time at The Analog Club, a new event series by the Studio by Copper + Cloves.Imagine walking into a busy cafe and seeing not a single phone, no-one taking selfies and no one around you scrolling. Disconnect from devices for 3 hours of unplugged experience—we'll have books, board games, music, crochet, and of course, food! But this isn't about structured activities or organised fun, just genuine connection and relaxation. The event will be fluid- you can dip into activities if you want, or you can just chat to new people or graze at our high tea counter!Meet new friends, sketch, play a board game or read a book in quiet solitude (without being surrounded by people lost in their phones).We will not be doing social media on our phones at the event, we will only take photos with a camera.Embrace the analog experience, slow down, and reconnect in this crazy digital age! **Strictly no devices for the entire duration you are present at the event (no laptops, ipads, phones) and you will be asked to keep your phone in a basket or in your bag- not in your pocket and no where on a table**Tickets are for entry and high tea from our renowned deli counter.

description: We’re excited to invite you to an exclusive breakfast and coffee preview of Muro Café, where Bangalore will experience the best of Asian breakfast and a celebration of Single Origin Coffees of Karnataka’s finest coffee estates. Join us on November 23rd & 24th for our Asian breakfast menu.From 9 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., experience Muro Cafe's unique twist on breakfast; from rich Crab Omelettes and indulgent Hong Kong French Toast to creamy Basque Cheesecake & more.Celebrate food, community, and the joy of coming together. Muro: https://www.instagram.com/murocafeblr/

name: Art is Life
description: November 30 & December 1Step into a world where art shapes life, and life inspires art. Join us for a weekend that celebrates art, culture, and community.Explore the Magic of Our Shared HeritageThis celebration invites you to dive into MAP’s rich and diverse collection, filled with treasures like timeless sculptures, beautiful textiles, pop culture memorabilia, and iconic photographs. These aren’t just museum pieces — they are a part of a collective cultural heritage that we all share.Be Part of the ArtThis year’s festival is packed with exciting new exhibitions, film screenings, hands-on workshops, live performances, and so much more. It’s not just a festival — it’s an immersive cultural adventure where art, history, and creativity come together to spark inspiration. Whether you are a seasoned art lover or just curious to explore something new, there’s no better place to experience the power of art than at Namma MAP.Come join us for Art is Life — where creativity blossoms, stories unfold, and art becomes a part of you!For more details and to register for workshops please visit https://map-india.org/art-is-life-2024/Art is Life 2024 is supported by Kingfisher Ultra Soda.

location.address: 22, Kasturba Rd, Shanthala Nagar, Ashok Nagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560001, India

organizer.name: Museum of Art and Photography (MAP Bengaluru)
organizer.description: MAP’s mission is to harness the transformative potential of art, to enrich lives, ignite creativity, and connect people.  We make art accessible and engaging for everyone through innovative experiences, meaningful dialogue and building communities.
